natural problem: What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number?
natural solution: Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.

However, counting all the outcomes in which four 6-sided dice do all show the same number is very easy: there are only 6 ways this can happen, namely all ones, all twos, all threes, all fours, all fives, and all sixes.

So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (1 - (1 / (6 powr 3)))"
shows  "probability = 215 / 216"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number? The final Answer is \frac{215}{216}
 ### Proof
 Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.
 However, counting all the outcomes in which four 6-sided dice do all show the same number is very easy: there are only 6 ways this can happen, namely all ones, all twos, all threes, all fours, all fives, and all sixes.
 So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (1 - (1 / (6 powr 3)))"
shows  "probability = 215 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the probability of the event not occurring if the probability of the event occurring is $\frac{1}{6^3}$. The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<longrightarrow> probability x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "indep_events (repeat 4 {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6})"
shows  "1 - (6 powr (-4)) = 215 / 216"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number? The final Answer is \frac{215}{216}
 ### Proof
 Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.
 However, counting all the outcomes in which four 6-sided dice do all show the same number is very easy: there are only 6 ways this can happen, namely all ones, all twos, all threes, all fours, all fives, and all sixes.
 So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<longrightarrow> probability x = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "indep_events (repeat 4 {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6})"
shows  "1 - (6 powr (-4)) = 215 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled 4 times independently. What is the probability of not getting the same number on all four rolls? The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability (\<lambda>x. x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}) = 1/6"
and h1 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. finite) (\<lambda>_. {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}) (\<lambda>_. 1/6) {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h2 : "prob_space (uniform_measure (count_space {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}))"
shows  "prob (measure (uniform_measure (count_space {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6})) {x. x \<noteq> x}) = 215 / 216"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number? The final Answer is \frac{215}{216}
 ### Proof
 Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.
 However, counting all the outcomes in which four 6-sided dice do all show the same number is very easy: there are only 6 ways this can happen, namely all ones, all twos, all threes, all fours, all fives, and all sixes.
 So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability (\<lambda>x. x \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}) = 1/6"
and h1 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. finite) (\<lambda>_. {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}) (\<lambda>_. 1/6) {1, 2, 3, 4}"
and h2 : "prob_space (uniform_measure (count_space {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}))"
shows  "prob (measure (uniform_measure (count_space {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6})) {x. x \<noteq> x}) = 215 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled four times. What is the probability that at least one of the four rolls results in a different number from the others? The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.

fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (1 - (1 / 6 powr 3)) * (1 / 6 powr 4)"
shows  "P = 215 / 216"

a_5.informal problem: Calculate the value of $P = (1 - \frac{1}{6^3}) \cdot \frac{1}{6^4}$. The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. 1 / (6^n))"
and h1 : "P 4 = 1 / 6^4"
shows  "1 - P 4 = 215 / 216"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number? The final Answer is \frac{215}{216}
 ### Proof
 Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.
 However, counting all the outcomes in which four 6-sided dice do all show the same number is very easy: there are only 6 ways this can happen, namely all ones, all twos, all threes, all fours, all fives, and all sixes.
 So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. 1 / (6^n))"
and h1 : "P 4 = 1 / 6^4"
shows  "1 - P 4 = 215 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If $P(n) = \frac{1}{6^n}$, find the value of $1 - P(4)$. The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Prod> _ \<leftarrow> [1..4]. (1 / 6))"
and h1 : "1 - probability = x"
shows  "x = 215 / 216"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number? The final Answer is \frac{215}{216}
 ### Proof
 Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.
 However, counting all the outcomes in which four 6-sided dice do all show the same number is very easy: there are only 6 ways this can happen, namely all ones, all twos, all threes, all fours, all fives, and all sixes.
 So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Prod> _ \<leftarrow> [1..4]. (1 / 6))"
and h1 : "1 - probability = x"
shows  "x = 215 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the probability of not getting a 1 when rolling a fair 6-sided die 4 times in a row? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. 1 - (1 / (6 powr n))^(n - 1))"
shows  "P 4 = 215 / 216"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that when we roll four fair 6-sided dice, they won't all show the same number? The final Answer is \frac{215}{216}

 Counting the number of outcomes in which four 6-sided dice don't all show the same number would require some pretty delicate casework.

 So since there are $6^4$ total outcomes, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice all show the same number}) = \frac{6}{6^4} = \frac{1}{6^3} = \frac{1}{216}. $$Therefore, using the principle of complementary probabilities, we can conclude that $$ P(\text{4 dice don't all show the same number}) = 1 - \frac{1}{216} = \boxed{\frac{215}{216}}.
 $$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. 1 - (1 / (6 powr n))^(n - 1))"
shows  "P 4 = 215 / 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the value of the expression $P(4) = 1 - \left(\frac{1}{6^4}\right)^{4 - 1}$, where $P$ is a function of $n$. The final answer is $\frac{215}{216}$.
